units.title: Collect primary tissue
units.text: Collect primary human tissue pieces, separated by biopsy site and/or tissue type (i.e., normal and tumor tissue) in 45 ml of ice-cold adDMEM/F12+++ medium in 50-ml conical tubes. (Optional) Add 10 µM ROCK inhibitor to adDMEM/F12+++ medium to increase cell survival. Keep tissue samples in this medium at 4 °C until the start of the isolation.
units.rationale: Initial step to obtain and preserve viable tissue for organoid generation.

units.title: Assess tissue composition
units.text: Assess whether obtained tissue pieces consist purely of epithelium or if they also contain fat or muscle tissue. If so, remove non-epithelial components as much as possible using surgical scissors or scalpels and forceps under a dissection microscope. If not, continue to the next step immediately.
units.rationale: Ensures only epithelial material proceeds to digestion, improving outgrowth efficiency.

units.title: Mince tissue
units.text: Mince the tissue into small fragments of 1–3 mm3 in a 10-cm cell culture dish using surgical scissors or scalpels.
units.rationale: Creates appropriately sized pieces for effective enzymatic digestion.

units.title: Fix representative fragments
units.text: Fix one or two representative fragments in ﬁxative (i.e., 10% (wt/vol) formalin or 4% (wt/vol) paraformaldehyde) for histological analysis.
units.rationale: Preserves samples for downstream histology to verify tissue integrity.

units.title: Snap‑freeze fragments for molecular analysis
units.text: Snap-freeze fragments for molecular (i.e., whole exome/genome sequencing or mRNA sequencing) or biochemical (i.e., Western blotting or proteomics) analysis at –80 °C. Such fragments may also be used to isolate DNA for quality controls/validation of patient of origin via SNP/STR fingerprinting.
units.rationale: Provides material for genomic and proteomic validation of the organoid source.

units.title: Digest tissue
units.text: Digest the tissue (from Step 3) as appropriate based on the tumor type (Table 1). Carefully monitor digestion, and for <2-h incubations, mix contents every 10–15 min by shaking vigorously and by pipetting the mixture up and down using a P1000 pipette. For overnight incubations, place the mixture on a shaker. Addition of 10 µM ROCK inhibitor during digestion can increase outgrowth efﬁciency. For head and neck organoids, digestion should not exceed 1 h and should be monitored regularly.
units.rationale: Enzymatically dissociates tissue into single cells or small clusters for plating.

units.title: Assist tissue disruption and wash
units.text: When the mixture becomes cloudy and the remaining tissue fragments are disrupted, further aid tissue disruption by pipetting up and down 10–20 times using a P1000 pipette. Wash once by topping up with 10 ml of adDMEM/F12+++ medium, and centrifuge at 200g for 5 min at 4 °C.
units.rationale: Ensures complete dissociation and removes debris before filtration.

units.title: Filter cell suspension
units.text: Resuspend the pellet in 10 ml of adDMEM/F12+++ medium, and ﬁlter using a 100-µm cell strainer.
units.rationale: Removes larger tissue fragments, yielding a uniform cell suspension.

units.title: Centrifuge filtered cells
units.text: Centrifuge the resuspended and ﬁltered cells at 200g for 5 min at 4 °C.
units.rationale: Pellets cells for subsequent resuspension in extracellular matrix.

units.title: Resuspend in BME/Matrigel
units.text: Aspirate the supernatant and resuspend the pellet in BME or Matrigel. BME should be kept on ice to prevent it from solidifying; thus, work quickly. The amount of BME depends on the size of the pellet. Approximately 10,000 cells should be plated in 40 µl of BME.
units.rationale: Encapsulates cells in a 3D matrix to support organoid formation.
